thread.title: Huckabee tells Iowans to vote for him or ‘for God’s sakes stay home’
thread.title_full: Huckabee tells Iowans to vote for him or ‘for God’s sakes stay home’ - MarketWatch

author: Robert Schroeder
title: Huckabee tells Iowans to vote for him or ‘for God’s sakes stay home’
text:
Mike Huckabee ain’t too proud to beg.
Speaking at the Iowa State Fair on Thursday, the former Arkansas governor and Republican presidential hopeful told attendees: “I don’t care how cold it is that night, please go vote for me” at Iowa’s presidential caucuses in February . According to National Journal, Huckabee continued: “And if for some crazy reason you are not gonna vote for me in the caucuses, for God’s sakes stay home that night where it’s warm and do not leave your home.” Huckabee won Iowa’s caucuses in 2008. As National Journal writes, the overwhelming support of Iowa’s social conservative voters that year catapulted him, if only temporarily, to the front of the presidential pack.
Biden wades further into 2016 bid: Vice President Joe Biden is wading further into a bid for the 2016 Democratic presidential nomination, writes the New York Times . A once bare-bones “Draft Biden” movement has entered a new and more aggressive phase that resembles an exploratory committee, the Times writes. On Wednesday night, Biden called one of his most outspoken political supporters and wrestled with the question of whether he should run. Biden directed Richard Harpootlian, the former chairman of the South Carolina Democratic Party, to get in touch with one of his closest political advisers, Mike Donilon, and has been calling other supporters, according to the Times.
Gore not planning to run: There is “no truth” to speculation that former Vice President Al Gore might jump into the 2016 presidential race, a Gore spokeswoman told Politico . On Thursday, Buzzfeed News posted a story saying that “supporters” of Gore “have begun a round of conversations among themselves and with the former vice president about his running for president in 2016, the latest sign that top Democrats have serious doubts that Hillary Clinton is a sure thing.” But that’s just not accurate, said Gore spokeswoman Betsy McManus. “There’s no truth to it. He’s laser-focused on solving the climate crisis,” she told Politico.
Fiorina on vaccines: Carly Fiorina believes parents should have the right to not vaccinate their children for all diseases . And, said the Republican presidential hopeful in Iowa on Thursday, schools should be able to exclude children who are unvaccinated for communicable diseases from attending classes. “When you have highly communicable diseases where you have a vaccine that’s proven, like measles or mumps, then I think a parent can make that choice,” Fiorina said, according to Time magazine. “But then I think a school district is well within their rights to say, ‘I’m sorry, your child cannot then attend public school.’”
Perry seen as first to drop out: Who’s going to be first to drop out of the presidential race? Former Texas Gov. Rick Perry , according to this week’s Politico Caucus, the publication’s weekly bipartisan survey of strategists, activists and operatives in Iowa and New Hampshire. Some 40% of early-state Republicans and nearly half of early-state Democrats think Perry, a Republican, will be first. “No money and cannot gain traction, even though he has the best record and a superb message,” said one Iowa Republican.
More from MarketWatch
